author: Richard Hartley-Parkinson
title: Man who left teenager for dead launches violent rampage after early release
text:
Brian Ramsay is back behind bars (Picture: SWNS) A man who brutally attacked a teenager leaving him with horrific facial injuries has gone on another criminal rampage.
Brian Ramsay attacked Angus Gallacher, 18, who was trying to help him.
Woman faked having cancer to con secret lover out of £38,000 Angus suffered 13 fractures to the face, three broken fingers, fractured ribs, a damaged ear drum after stopping to help Ramsay who he found lying on his back at a petrol station.
As he helped him across the road, Ramsay turned on Angus in a brutal attack.
Ramsay then dragged the teenager to a nearby house where he tried to clean the teenager up, but he then attacked him again before leaving him for dead in the street.
He beat up Angus Gallagher in 2015 (Picture: SWNS) Angus was eventually found by neighbours and was then taken to the resuscitation unit at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary.
Homeless people turned into 'zombies' as a result of new strain of Spice He was transferred to St John’s Hospital, in Livingston, and remained there for a further five days in recovery.
More recently, Ramsay was released from a 39-month prison sentence on June 10 last year and started offending as early as July 8.
He became part of an organised crime gang, according to the Daily Record, who burgle people’s houses and nick high-end cars.
Angus took a selfie showing his injuries (Picture: SWNS) Ramsay has now pleaded guilty to 26 new offences including a raid at a Pizza Express in in which he stole £2,000 from a safe.
UK zoo where 500 animals died to find out if it can keep its licence They also took £2,200 in cigarettes from a shop and stole a BMW X4 and Audi Q3 as getaway cars for other burglaries.
He has now been jailed to serve the remaining 556 days left from his 39-month sentence.
Fiscal depute Aidan Higgins told the court: ‘The accused’s offending in this case arises from his significant involvement as a principal member of an organised crime gang.’
